Introduce as many technical people to dPoW and Notary Nodes.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: maybe we can focus on specific other communities, such as debian package maintainers, and open source project people that have all the skills, but probably never heard of us

Author: SHossain#0007
Content:
here is a spec of bare metal that is being used as mainnet NN
```
Chassis:    Intel 1U Server System R1208WFTYS, 8x 2.5" Drive Bays
Processor:    2x Intel Xeon Gold 6134 Processor - 8 Cores, 3.20GHz, 24.75MB Cache
Memory:    4x 32GB 2400MHz Samsung DDR4 ECC Registered DIMM Module
Storage: 2x 1TB Samsung 960 PRO NMVe M.2
Power Supply: 2x 80 Plus Platinum 1100w, redundant PSU
```

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: building your own server and using co-location is ideal

Author: Dr.Terminus#3269

Author: Dr.Terminus#3269
Content: I'm prob going to wind up having to go the dedicated hosting route. Wish I had started research  on hardware involved sooner

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: still not too late to start

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's a good time to start, most people haven't

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and while lots of HW is good, mostly you need unlimited bandwidth, decent peering and lots of HD space. Some people use small VPSs, but they do more work to keep things performant. Beefier HW gives you some buffer

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i don't recommend spending more than maybe $300 month. You can get physical 8 core machines for much less than that, which is what I used. Some NN ops use digitalocean droplets with huge amounts of cronjob automation. ymmv

Author: jorian#4555
Content: wallet management is a sizeable part of being notary

Author: jorian#4555
Content: if you get that right, you're a good notary. then 8-16 threads is plenty, no need to have 48 threads when iguana only uses one of them

Author: kolo#1111
Content: I would recommend >1Tb SSD. Ultra mega high expensive, but would do the job in case of buying hardware. Can happen we won't fit in 1Tb next year

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: yeah, we don't control the size of external coins that add dpow

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: how much space do you currently need to run all notarized chains on a nn?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: well, i have to go around and delete unnecessary junk to make room, if that helps ðŸ˜ƒ I will look

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `/dev/md4        392G  358G   15G  97% /home`

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: just BTC is 200GB of that

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: thanks not too bad

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: 500GB disk is too small for next year

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: each new external coin we add is a few more GBs, and then of course all chains keep growing

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: and ram wise how much do you have used?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: changes over time i would say

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: 64GB ram

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: iguana is using 13% of it

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: less ram might suffice, i am not sure. sometimes there are memory leaks in iguana tho...

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i know some NNs have said iguana filled up their RAM sometimes. having more is a buffer against that

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: yes

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i know that @lukechilds probably runs the NN server with the "smallest" specs, a digitalocean droplet, and he gets very good numbers from lots of automation.  Not sure of the exact specs

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: we use a physical 8 core box

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: one massively important thing: make sure you don't pay for bandwidth!

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: yes ec2 is no good:)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: running this stuff on AWS and paying for bandwidth would be crazy expensive

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: I have on the explorers alone 2TB out per month

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: free bandwidth, and good peering. See how many hops you are from other NNs

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @CHMEX yep, that is a lot ðŸ˜ƒ I paid $400 in one month for Hush explorer bandwidth fees once, learned my lesson

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: outsch that hurts

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: https://github.com/chainstrike/nntools/blob/master/nn_ips.pl

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that tool will help you sort all NN IP's by how many hops they are from you

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: we use it to connect to the closest/best NNs, but also good to see which NNs are close to a given IP

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: nice
